sen.j: 若年より実父信西譲りの才智をもって登用され、大学権助、東宮学士などを経て、保元元年（1156年）の保元の乱の後の除目で右少弁に任官。
sen.e: He was, early in life, appointed to the government positions due to his talent and intelligence inherited from his natural father, Shinzei, and after served as Daigaku no gon no suke, Togu gakushi (Teacher of the Classics of the Crown Prince) and so on, appointed as Ushoben (Minor Controller of the Right) at the time of Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) following the Hogen Disturbance in 1156.

Due to the talent and intelligence that he had inherited from his father, Shinzei, he was given government positions while still young, serving as Daigaku no Gon no Suke (Provisional Assistant Director of the Bureau of Education) and Togu Gakushi (Teacher of the Classics to the Crown Prince) amongst others and, following the Hogen Disturbance in 1156, he was appointed Ushoben (Minor Controller of the Right).

sen.j: 以後、父の権勢をも背景として要職を歴任し、左少弁蔵人、左衛門権佐、東宮学士を兼帯した際には「希代」のことと評された（『兵範記』・保元2年（1157年）10月23日条）。
sen.e: Afterward, backed by his father's power, he successively filled various important posts and when he concurrently held the posts of Sashoben (third-ranked officer of the left) Kurodo (Chamberlain) ("Heihanki" (diary of TAIRA no Nobunori) December 3, 1157 Section).

sen.j: 父信西は殺害され、さらに戦後、戦乱を招いた責任によりその子息は悉く流罪に処せられる。
sen.e: His father, Shinzei was killed, and further after the Disturbance, Shinzei's sons were all banished being made to take responsibility for the Disturbance.

sen.j: 俊憲も解官の上越後国（後に阿波国に変更）に配流となり、これを契機に出家して法名を真寂と称した。
sen.e: Toshinori was also deprived of his positions and exiled to Echigo province (changed to Awa Province later), and taking that opportunity, he became a priest and called himself Shinjaku, his Homyo (a name given to a person who enters the Buddhist priesthood).

sen.j: 翌永暦 (日本)元年（1160年）には召還されるが、その後は表舞台に立つことなく、仁安2年に死去した。
sen.e: He was recalled in the following year, 1160, but afterward, he never went mainstream and died in 1167.

sen.e: "Gukansho " (Jottings of a Fool), "Kojidan" (Talks of the Past) and "Zoku kojidan" contained anecdotes about his talent for writing and the August 23, 1184 section of "Gyokuyo" (Diary of FUJIWARA no Kanezane) introduced, as a ' proverb of wise man,' a prediction he had made saying that 'War will not cease as far as the retired emperor Goshirakawa holds power.'
